    Copy Number Variations (CNV)

    spata-v2-cnv-analysis.Rmd

    1. Introduction

    InferCNV is used to identify large-scale chromosomal copy number alterations in single cell RNA-Seq data including gains or deletions of chromosomes or large segments of such. Several publications have leveraged this technique. (Patel et al., 2014, Tirosh et al., 2016, Venteicher et al., 2017 )

    # load package
library(SPATA2)

# load glioblastoma sample
spata_obj <- loadSpataObject("data/spata-obj-gbm275.RDS")

    SPATA2 implements the package infercnv published and maintained by Broadinstitute and allows to integrate this technique in your workflow of analysing spatial trancsriptomic data derived from malignancies.

    2. Running CNV-Analysis

    As with all other functions prefixed with run*() the function runCnvAnalysis() is a wrapper around all necessary functions needed to conduct copy-number-variation-analysis. The results needed for subsequent analysis steps are stored in the specified spata-object (slot: @cnv). The infercnv-object is stored in the folder specified in the argument directory_cnv_folder.

    spata_obj <-
  runCnvAnalysis(
    object = spata_obj
    directory_cnv_folder = "data-gmb275/cnv-results" # example directory
    cnv_prefix = "Chr"
    )

    If your desired set up deviates from the default you can reach any function of the inferncnv-pipeline by entering it’s name as an argument and specify it’s input as a list of arguments with which you want it to be called.

    # change input
spata_obj <- 
  runCnvAnalysis(
    object = spata_obj
    directory_cnv_folder = "data-gmb275/cnv-results" # example directory to 
    clear_noise_via_ref_mean_sd = list(sd_amplifier = 2)
    )

    Copy number variation analysis requires reference data. This includes a count matrix from healthy tissue, an annotation file as well as a data.frame that contains information about the chromosome positions. We provide reference data in the list SPATA2::cnv_ref.

    names(cnv_ref)
    ## [1] "annotation" "mtr"        "regions"
    summary(cnv_ref)
    ##            Length   Class      Mode   
## annotation        1 data.frame list   
## mtr        71067022 -none-     numeric
## regions           4 data.frame list

    runCnvAnalysis() defaults to the content of this list. The documentation of runCnvAnalysis() contains a detailed description of the requirements each reference input must meet in order for the function to work.

    # example on how to use the functions arguments if you want to specify the reference (ref_*)
runCnvAnalysis(
  object = spata_obj,
  directory_cnv_folder = "data-gmb275/cnv-results", # example directory to 
  ref_annotation = cnv_ref$annotation, 
  ref_mtr = cnv_ref$mtr, 
  ref_regions = cnv_ref$regions
)

    3. CNV-Results

    The results are stored in a list inside the spata-object. This list can be obtained via getCnvResults().

    cnv_results <- getCnvResults(spata_obj)

names(cnv_results)
    ## [1] "prefix"      "gene_pos_df" "cnv_df"      "cnv_mtr"     "regions_df" 
## [6] "dim_red"     "clustering"

    4. Visualization

    The gains and losses of chromosomal segments can be displayed via plotCnvResults().

    plotCnvResults(object = spata_obj)

    Figure 4.1 Copy Number Alterations for the whole sample.

    If you want to visualize the results across certain groups to identify subclones make use of the across-argument.

    plotSurface(object = spata_obj, color_by = "seurat_clusters")

plotCnvResults(object = spata_obj, across = "seurat_clusters")

    Figure 4.2 Copy Number Alterations across specific groups.

    Apart from that you obtain a heatmap that is directly plotted into the folder specified with argument directory_cnv_results.

    Figure 4.3 CNV-Heatmap

    Note: We are currently encountering problems with the function infercnv:::plot_cnv(). It does not prevent the copy number variation analysis. Sometimes, however, the heatmap is not plotted. Checkout your R console for hints in how far the function did not work properly. We are working on a solution for that. If you encounter warnings raised from runCnvAnalysis() let us know.

    The numeric values by which the copy number variations within each barcode-spot are represented are immediately transferred to the spata-object’s feature data and are thus accessible for all functions that work with numeric variables. The character string specified in argument cnv_prefix combined with the chromosomes number determines the name by which you can refer to these feature variables.

    # cnv feature names
getCnvFeatureNames(object = spata_obj)
    ##  [1] "Chr1"  "Chr1"  "Chr2"  "Chr2"  "Chr3"  "Chr3"  "Chr4"  "Chr4"  "Chr5" 
## [10] "Chr5"  "Chr6"  "Chr6"  "Chr7"  "Chr7"  "Chr8"  "Chr8"  "Chr9"  "Chr9" 
## [19] "Chr10" "Chr10" "Chr11" "Chr11" "Chr12" "Chr12" "Chr13" "Chr13" "Chr14"
## [28] "Chr14" "Chr15" "Chr15" "Chr16" "Chr16" "Chr17" "Chr17" "Chr18" "Chr18"
## [37] "Chr19" "Chr19" "Chr20" "Chr20" "Chr21" "Chr21" "Chr22" "Chr22"
    # are part of all feature names
getFeatureNames(object = spata_obj)
    ##            numeric            integer            numeric            numeric 
##   "nCount_Spatial" "nFeature_Spatial"       "percent.mt"       "percent.RB" 
##             factor          character             factor             factor 
##  "seurat_clusters"     "segmentation"      "Leiden_UMAP"          "cluster" 
##            logical            numeric            numeric            numeric 
##             "keep"             "Chr0"             "Chr1"            "Chr10" 
##            numeric            numeric            numeric            numeric 
##            "Chr11"            "Chr12"            "Chr13"            "Chr14" 
##            numeric            numeric            numeric            numeric 
##            "Chr15"            "Chr16"            "Chr17"            "Chr18" 
##            numeric            numeric            numeric            numeric 
##            "Chr19"             "Chr2"            "Chr20"            "Chr21" 
##            numeric            numeric            numeric            numeric 
##            "Chr22"            "Chr23"             "Chr3"             "Chr4" 
##            numeric            numeric            numeric            numeric 
##             "Chr5"             "Chr6"             "Chr7"             "Chr8" 
##            numeric 
##             "Chr9"

    Figure 4.3 as well as figure 4.1 indicate that the glioblastoma sample contains losses in chromosome 10 and gains in chromosome 7 and that these alterations affect cluster 1 particularly strong while disregarding cluster 2 (upper-left) of the grouping variable seurat_clusters. Use plotSurface() to visualize these subclones on your sample’s surface.

    plotSurface(object = spata_obj, color_by = "Chr7", pt_clrsp = "Reds 3", c1 = 1)

plotSurface(object = spata_obj, color_by = "Chr10", pt_clrsp = "Blues 3", rev = FALSE, c1 = 1)

    Figure 4.4 Spatial visualization of areas that are affected by chromosomal alterations.
